Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis and Design Workshop: Weaving the Fabric of Adaptive STEM Learning Environments Across Domains and Settings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop is funded through the "Dear Colleague Letter: Principles for the Design of Digital Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Learning Environments (NSF 18-017)." The goal of this workshop is to articulate a transformative vision of future STEM learning for diverse learners across domains and settings. It forges a nexus among the emerging (a) sciences of learning, (b) assessment, and (c) big data to formulate frameworks and tools for designing STEM learning environments. Taking an equity-first approach for broadening participation through innovative designs, this project convenes interdisciplinary teams to produce a white paper proposing forward-looking digitally-augmented STEM environments that bridge formal and informal learning contexts and are responsive to the needs to every learner. The white paper will also articulate a future research agenda that could lead to new breakthroughs at the Human-Technology Frontier. The open-invitation design workshop, strategically located at Stanford University, and dissemination through a public website and community outreach activities at key conferences in which these scholarly communities convene will ensure broad awareness of and access to these models, tools, frameworks, design principles, and research priorities for educators, researchers, and analysts.

The workshop is designed to construct needed new collaborations with the learning sciences, psychometrics, and computer science to design integrative STEM learning environments with robust in-process measures of adaptive learning that address key aspects of deeper learning. It convenes innovators advancing the state-of-the-art in equity-focused, technology-enhanced STEM learning, educational data mining and learning analytics, and computational psychometrics, to develop innovative ways to design and scale for a future of integrated STEM learning in an era of big data. An infrastructure of generative new algorithms and knowledge models, psychometric models, and learner pathway models will emerge from project activities at the intersection of these disciplinary perspectives to transform learning and assessment designs by incorporating signals from multimodal learning analytics and software for multi-faceted measurement of academic competencies. The project scope will be guided by three questions: (1) How can learning environments for integrated STEM learning scale successful efforts across diverse student populations and bridge formal and informal learning contexts? (2) What innovative research methods, statistical techniques and modeling formalisms are necessary to embed theoretical models in data-driven computational approaches in order to capture, characterize and support causal claims about individual and team-based learning, especially for complex, multi-source streaming data? (3) How can multi-domain threaded learning progressions be created for integrated learning and assessment of STEM subjects?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this workshop project was to articulate a transformative vision of and principles for designing for diverse learners in future Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Learning Environments integrated across domains, settings and times. We sought to forge a nexus of new collaborations with the learning sciences, assessment, and computer science (data-intensive research) communities to formulate frameworks and tools for designing STEM learning environments with robust in-process measures of adaptive learning that address key aspects of deeper learning. Taking an equity-first approach for broadening participation through inventive designs, this project convened interdisciplinary teams of scholars and innovators to identify and propose forward-looking digitally augmented STEM environments that bridge formal and informal learning contexts to be inclusively responsive to every learner’s needs. The open-invitation design workshop was convened at Stanford University. The convening and subsequent dissemination through a website and community outreach activities at key conferences have ensured broad awareness of and access to the products of this project, especially design principles and research priorities for educators, researchers, and technologists. The resulting white paper articulates a research agenda that could lead to new breakthroughs at the Human-Technology Frontier.

Three questions guided project scope: (1) How can learning environments for integrated STEM learning scale successful efforts across diverse student populations and bridge formal and informal learning contexts? (2) What innovative research methods, statistical techniques and modeling formalisms are necessary to embed theoretical models in data-driven computational approaches in order to capture, characterize and support causal claims about individual and team-based learning, especially for complex, multi-source streaming data? (3) How can multi-domain threaded learning progressions be created for integrated learning and assessment of STEM subjects?

Workshop participants provided state-of-the-art examples of learning that bridges K-12 formal/informal learning and which integrates STEM disciplines and rich learning data capture. Cross-specialization groups then designed learning environment vignettes comprising integrative STEM learning environments over space and time, emphasizing the roles of interest-driven learning for learning persistence and depth. Participants prioritized the importance of advancing the state-of-the-art of knowledge mapping to articulate relationships between learning progressions across multiple domains and settings. Weaving data-driven integrated learning and assessment-for-learning-experiences across multiple STEM domains into threaded learning progressions of STEM subjects will be vital for learner developing expertise. Participants stressed the importance of developing longitudinal STEM learning data on interests, achievements, and socio-emotional learning across domains and settings to support the desired vision of adaptive integrated STEM learning.

Group collaborative writing processes resulted in six design principles that best frame the future of technology-enhanced STEM learning environments congruent with the workshop vision. These synthetic principles reflect the need to merge best practices in teaching and learning with innovative technology, and to articulate how learning technology can improve by careful reconsideration of ways for integrating technology into learning spaces that recognize the dynamic nature of learning across disciplines and contexts.

Workshop participants defined a set of research agenda priorities for near-term, medium-term, and longer-term research for informing the workshop vision of designs of future STEM Learning Environments integrated across domains, settings, and times. Workshop groups surfaced a variety of construct definition and measurement goals as needing specification and cumulative knowledge building for each of these three programmatic temporal horizons. In sum, anytime-anywhere integrative STEM learning requires computing architectures which will enable adaptive recommendations which can establish personalized learning pathways cued from identified learner interests and adaptive learning activity recommendations to fulfill the aims of integrative STEM learning for all learners.

The vision of technology-enhanced adaptive integrative STEM learning requires recognition of tensions inherent in this ambitious approach for improving STEM learning. Workshop participants outlined primary tensions for deliberative considerations to make progress. For example, capturing data for creating comprehensive cross-context learner profiles should better adaptively serve learning needs. Yet such data connectedness of in and out of school learning data carries learner privacy risks. Another tension is between a focus on mapping learning progressions within each STEM domain and the need for tracking progress toward integrated STEM knowledge. Displacing human interactions with opaque AI algorithms versus co-evolving better human-computer systems to foster adaptively integrated STEM learning was also highlighted as a tension. While teachers today make real-time decisions about student learning needs, the synergistic use of AI must carefully assess and be able to explain to teachers and learners when and how AI adaptive algorithms make recommendations for what to learn, when to learn it, and why a learner should be learning a given topic.

Beyond the white paper shared publicly on the NSF Center for Innovative Research in Cyberlearning (CIRCL) website, the project leadership is presenting a paper on key findings from this effort at the International Conference of the Learning Sciences in Nashville, Summer 2020. Work-in-progress includes a CIRCL Rapid Community Report as well as envisioning papers authored by workshop participants addressing the three guiding project questions.
